'''''Sarcodon imbricatus''''', commonly known as the '''shingled hedgehog''' or '''scaly hedgehog''', is a species of [[tooth fungus]] in the order [[Thelephorales]]. The mushroom is [[edible mushroom|edible]].  Many sources report it has a bitter taste, but others have found it delicious and suspect that the bitter specimens may be similar related species.<ref name="Wells 1970"/> The mushroom has a large, brownish [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] with large brown scales and may reach 30 cm (12 in) in diameter. On the underside it sports greyish, brittle teeth instead of [[lamella (mycology)|gills]], and has white [[trama (mycology)|flesh]]. Its [[spore print]] is brown. It is associated with spruce (''[[Picea]]''), appearing in autumn. It ranges throughout North America and Europe, although collections from the British Isles are now assigned to the similar species ''[[Sarcodon squamosus]]''.

==Taxonomy==
The Swedish botanist [[Olof Celsius]] reported in 1732 that ''Sarcodon imbricatus'' occurred in the vicinity of [[Uppsala]], and [[Carl Linnaeus]] wrote of it in his 1737 work ''Flora lapponica''.<ref name=Nilper>{{cite book |author1=Nilson S.  |author2=Persson O.  |lastauthoramp=yes | year = 1977 | title = Fungi of Northern Europe 1: Larger Fungi (Excluding Gill-Fungi) | publisher = Penguin|isbn=0-14-063005-8|page=76}}</ref> It was one of the species initially described by Linnaeus, as ''Hydnum imbricatum'', in the second volume of his ''[[Species Plantarum]]'' in 1753.<ref>{{cite book | last=Linnaeus | first=C | authorlink=Carl Linnaeus | title=Species Plantarum: Tomus II | publisher=Holmiae. (Laurentii Salvii). | date=1753| page=1178|language=la}}</ref> The [[botanical name|specific epithet]] is the [[Latin]] ''imbricatus'' meaning "tiled" or "with overlapping tiles".<ref>{{cite book | last = Simpson | first = D.P. | title = Cassell's Latin Dictionary | publisher = Cassell Ltd. | date= 1979 | edition = 5 | location = London | page = 883 | isbn = 0-304-52257-0}}</ref> It was then placed in the genus ''[[Sarcodon]]'' by Finnish mycologist [[Petter Adolf Karsten]] in 1881.

For many years, ''Sarcodon imbricatus'' was described associated with both spruce and pine, although the latter forms were smaller and noted to be more palatable by mushroom hunters in Norway. Furthermore, the mushroom has been used as a source of pigment and collectors noted that fresh specimens collected under pine yielded [[biological pigment|pigment]], but only old ones collected under spruce. [[molecular phylogenetics|Molecular]] analysis of the DNA revealed the two forms to be distinct genetically, and thus populations of what had been described as ''S. imbricatus'' were now assigned to ''[[Sarcodon squamosus]]'', which includes collections in the British Isles and the Netherlands.<ref name=Joh99>{{cite journal |author1=Johanneson H |author2=Ryman S |author3=Lundmark H |author4=Danell E. |year=1999|title=''Sarcodon imbricatus'' and ''S. squamosus'' – two confused species |journal=Mycological Research |volume=103 |issue=11 |pages=1447–52 |doi=10.1017/S0953756299008709}}</ref>

==Description==
The mushrooms, or fruiting bodies, can be quite large in size. the brownish or greyish [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] measures up to 30 cm (12 in) in diameter and is covered with coarse darker brown scales. It is funnel-shaped. The underside bears soft, pale grey 'teeth' rather than gills. These are 0.5–1 cm long and brittle. The pale grey or brown [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]] may reach {{convert|8|cm|in|1}} high and {{convert|3|cm|in|1}} wide, and may be narrower at the base and is sometimes eccentric.<ref name=Nilper/><ref name=Joh99/><ref name=Haas69>{{cite book | last = Haas |first=Hans | year = 1969 | title = The Young Specialist looks at Fungi |page= 170| publisher = Burke | isbn= 0-222-79409-7}}</ref>

From above, it may be confused with the old man of the woods (''[[Strobilomyces strobilaceus]]'') as both have a similar shaggy cap.<ref name=Haas69/> The bitter and inedible ''[[Sarcodon amarascens]]'' can be distinguished by its bluish-black stipe.<ref name=Zeitl76>{{cite book|last=Zeitlmayr |first=Linus|year=1976|title=Wild Mushrooms:An Illustrated Handbook|publisher=Garden City Press, Hertfordshire|isbn= 0-584-10324-7|page= 106}}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
The fruit bodies of ''Sarcodon imbricatus'' grow in association with firs (''[[Abies]]''), especially in hilly or mountainous areas,<ref name=Zeitl76/> and can appear on sandy or chalk soils in [[fairy ring]]s.<ref name=Haas69/> The usual fruiting season in August to October.<ref name=Nilper/> It ranges throughout North America and Europe,<ref name=arora86>{{cite book |last=[[David Arora|Arora]] |first=David |year=1986 |title=Mushrooms demystified: a comprehensive guide to the fleshy fungi |edition=2nd |location=Berkeley |publisher=Ten Speed Press |isbn=0-89815-169-4 |pages=620 |url-access=registration |url=https://archive.org/details/mushroomsdemysti00aror_0 }}</ref> although collections from the British Isles are now assigned to another species, ''[[Sarcodon squamosus]]''.<ref name=Phillips06>{{cite book | author = Phillips R | year = 2006 | title = Mushrooms | publisher = Pan MacMillan|location=London | isbn = 0-330-44237-6|page=323}}</ref>

==Uses==
Old mushrooms of ''Sarcodon imbricatus'' and related species contain blue-green pigments, which are used for [[mushroom dye|dyeing]] wool in Norway.<ref>Rice M, Beebee D. (1980). ''Mushrooms for Color''. Mad River Press : Eureka.</ref>

===Edibility===
The fungus can be bitter, although this is less apparent in younger specimens. Submerging the mushrooms in boiling water will remove this.<ref name=Haas69/> It can be pickled or dried and used as flavouring.<ref name=Zeitl76/> In Bulgaria it is collected, dried and finely ground to be used as an aromatic mushroom [[flour]].<ref>{{cite book | author = Z. Angelova | title = Гъбите в България | publisher = Картография ЕООД (Bulgaria) }}</ref> It is reported as [[edible mushroom|edible]] but of poor quality in the United States by some sources<ref name=arora86/> but as deliciously edible by others.<ref name="Wells 1970"/>

In [[Korean cuisine|Korea]], [[mushroom tea]] is made from it.
